sentences.sentence: By Susan J. CrockfordCanadian government scientists created headline news(https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2022/12/24/world/polar-bear-population-decline/) worldwide just before Christmas when they told the media Western Hudson Bay polar bear numbers appear to have declined by 27 per cent between 2017 and 2021, according to a survey report that still has not been made public.

This is called "science by press release(https://scopeblog.stanford.edu/2013/10/28/the-disturbing-trend-of-science-by-press-release/)," a practice that is actually anti-scientific, since real science proceeds by publication, criticism, debate and either replication or refutation.Not surprisingly, virtually all the media stories either stated or implied a strong association between this purported population decline and a lack of sea ice due to climate change(https://financialpost.com/tag/climate-change/).

But in fact sea ice conditions have been particularly good over the past five years - for both freeze-up(https://polarbearscience.com/2022/11/17/hudson-bay-sea-ice-freeze-up-in-2022-like-the-1980s-for-the-5th-time-since-2015/) and break-up dates(https://polarbearscience.com/2021/06/23/polar-bears-of-western-hudson-bay-still-on-the-ice-at-third-week-june/) - calling into question how "lack of sea ice" could possibly be to blame for the apparent decline.To its credit, a Reuters story(https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/canadas-hudson-bay-polar-bear-population-plummets-climate-change-warms-arctic-2022-12-23/) (first issued Dec. 23) both indicated this was the case and included another critical caveat: "climate-caused changes in the local seal population might be driving bear numbers down."

Only one other story I saw, from BBC News(https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-64083507), mentioned the possible effect from the seal population.Without being able to check the actual report there is not much more that can be said.

Although several news stories claimed the report was recently released, it is still not publicly available on the relevant page(https://www.gov.nu.ca/environnement/information/wildlife-research-reports#polarbear) of the Nunavut government website, nor anywhere else online that I could find.

None of the news reports linked to the study, cited its title or even linked to an official press release.Judging from the Reuters story(https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/canadas-hudson-bay-polar-bear-population-plummets-climate-change-warms-arctic-2022-12-23/), however, it appears the study's authors were unable to make a definitive link between sea ice loss and a decline in polar bear numbers in Western Hudson Bay, despite what they or others might have told the media.What about ringed seals, the bears' primary prey?
Did ringed seal numbers decline between 2017 and 2021, creating a lack of food for bears in Hudson Bay?
If so, is there a clear correlation between declining ringed seal numbers and a lack of sea ice, as implied by the Reuters statement quoted above?The short answers are "no" and "no."

Studies of ringed seals in Hudson Bay indicate no definitive cause and effect between sea ice changes and seal health and survival, primarily because there hasn't been a declining trend in sea ice coverage.

As a 2020 study(https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ecog.04988) in the journal Ecography put it: "Our trend analysis of environ mental variables indicated a strong warming pattern prior to 1999.
Following this decisive shift, the region has dem onstrated no warming trend.
Still, the 2000 to 2016 body conditions trend (for the seals) was negative suggesting an overall decline in ringed seal body fat over this period."

Ringed seal females with much less body fat may fail to produce viable pups in the spring, thus reducing the prey available for polar bears.William Watson: Central bankers should read Paul Volcker on taking down inflation(https://financialpost.com/opinion/central-bankers-paul-volcker-taking-down-inflation)Jack Mintz: Federal employment growth is now out of hand(https://financialpost.com/opinion/jack-mintz-federal-employment-growth-is-now-out-of-hand)Opinion: We won't make Ottawa's 2030 emissions targets and it won't even be close(https://financialpost.com/opinion/ottawa-2030-emissions-targets)Another possibility is that deeper than usual springtime snow may have protected ringed seal pups (born in "snow caves" on the sea ice) from polar bear predation.
This would effectively reduce food available to bears, especially if pregnant seals were only slightly less fat and produced pups as usual.

But no studies measure snow depth over ice on Hudson Bay.Thus even if there has been a decline in polar bear numbers, as the authors of the new study claim to have found, it is not at all clear what might be to blame.

If some bears were not finding enough seals to eat over the last few years and have been starving to death, the question remains why fewer seals were available.In sum, the facts are that there are no data linking a critical lack of sea ice to poor health or abundance for either polar bears or their ringed seal prey in Western Hudson Bay between 2017 and 2021.

Despite this, the authors of a government report on polar bear numbers that is not yet publicly available apparently felt comfortable telling the media that lack of sea ice could be blamed for an apparent decline in polar bear abundance over the last five years and that this confirms earlier predictions that this is exactly what would happen because of human-caused global warming.Like other scientists, I'll assess the actual report when it is made publicly available.

In the meantime, we're stuck with the press-release science: a sensational narrative surrounding findings of as yet undetermined scientific merit.Susan J. Crockford is a zoologist and author of the books The Polar Bear Catastrophe That Never Happened(https://www.amazon.ca/Polar-Bear-Catastrophe-Never-Happened/dp/0993119085) and Fallen Icon: Sir David Attenborough and the Walrus Deception.
(https://www.amazon.ca/Fallen-Icon-Attenborough-Walrus-Deception/dp/0991796691) !
